Award.AwardTitle: Topological Physics and Light Matter Interactions: From Floquet Topological Insulators to Solar Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Division of Physics contribute funds to this award which supports theoretical research and education focused on means to stabilize and utilize topological behavior through light-matter interactions in a variety of systems. Topological insulators possess some amazing properties such as the ability to conduct electricity without dissipation at their boundaries while being insulating through their interior. The research which will be carried out under this award is geared toward extending concepts of topological behavior of matter when it interacts with light. This presents a fertile ground for fundamental and applied research.

The research will concentrate on three themes. The first is to employ topological insulator surfaces for energy harvesting and detection of infra-red light. The second is to use light to turn an ordinary insulator into a topological insulator. The third is to create unique edge states in a hybrid system of a semiconductor in a cavity that could bridge semiconductor and optical technologies.

This research has the potential of introducing new techniques for energy harvesting and light detection and paving the way to new photonic devices based on topological principles. The award will allow training of graduate students and postdocs in an interdisciplinary research environment at the intersection of materials physics and optics. The PI will involve undergraduate students in this research and incorporate the research material into the undergraduate level course that he has developed at Caltech.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Division of Physics contribute funds to this award which supports theoretical research and education focused on means to stabilize and utilize topological behavior through light-matter interactions in a variety of systems. The first part of the project is focused on turning the surface of three-dimensional (3D) topological insulators into a photovoltaic platform aimed at the elusive mid-wavelength infrared spectrum. The surface electrons of 3D topological insulators typically have a minute photocurrent response to incident light in spite of the fact that many electron-hole pairs form. The PI will exploit the spin-orbit locking on the surface to turn it into a photocurrent rectifier. This can be done using a magnetic grating deposited on the surface which should result in a substantial photocurrent response to circularly polarized light. The PI will consider the manifestations of this effect in realistic topological insulators, its optimization with respect to the magnetic pattern deposited, and its extension to other systems, such as two-dimensional (2D) topological insulators and 2D quantum wells with Rashba interaction.

In the second part the PI will study ways to induce topological behavior in trivial semiconductors using coherent light. Electrons in semiconductors driven into a topological phase exhibit a non-equilibrium energy distribution determined by the strength of the drive and various relaxation mechanisms. By deriving these distributions, the PI will investigate under what circumstances the non-equilibrium effects do not obstruct the topological behavior of the driven system, and analyze schemes to detect this so-called Floquet topological phase.

The third part of the project is focused on the possibility of creating topological polariton states in optical waveguides coupled to trivial semiconductors. Relying on the idea of the Floquet topological insulator, the PI will examine whether it is possible to have a topological bound state of a cavity photon and an exciton in a topologically trivial semiconducting quantum well. A topological polariton state may exhibit strongly enhanced lifetimes, as well as could be used as a nanophotonic isolator.

This research has the potential of introducing new techniques for energy harvesting and light detection and paving the way to new photonic devices based on topological principles. The award will allow training of graduate students and postdocs in an interdisciplinary research environment at the intersection of materials physics and optics. The PI will involve undergraduate students in this research and incorporate the research material into the undergraduate level course that he has developed at Caltech.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new paradigm for quantum behavior in materials has emerged over the last decade. Topological quantum phases have been predicted and detected in a variety of materials. These materials exhibit a variety of interesting behaviors. For instance they could be insulating in the bulk, but conducting on their surface. Their electrons typically exhibit complete spin orbit locking, which means that their spin direction is always at a fixed angle relative to the direction of their motion.

The grant provided by NSF was used to develop ways to capitalize on this remarkable new behavior, as well as find new ways to induce such behavior in systems where light and matter interact strongly. First, we asked: can we use the new topological materials as light harvesters for infrared? Could they augment solar cell technology due to their gapless and special magnetic behavior and allow to harvest in the IR regime where current solar cells perform poorly? Could they be used as fast detectors for IR? We showed that two classes of materials could be at the basis of such detectors. A magnetically patterned topological insulator surface, as well as Weyl semimetals could be adjusted to detect mid to far IR even at room temperature, we theorized.

Next, we asked, could we induce topological behavior in photons by coupling light to excitons in regular semiconductors? The result would be a polariton – an excitation which is part light and part electronic – that would be bound to the edges of a sample (see fig. 1). Furthermore, such topological polaritons would move only in one direction, and not its opposite. We found a variety of schemes for such behavior to occur, both in systems where light and matter couple, as well as in electronic exciton systems.

Finally, we considered a variety of quantum phases that could emerge when we periodically modulate a system. We showed that such modulations can produce quantum pahses with chiral edge modes that have no analog in static systems. Also, we demonstrated how a system could be shielded from heating despite being strongly driven. Over the last year, we began using the combination of topological-behavior principles and periodic drives to expand our ability to control light and matter. In what forms the basis of our future research, we showed that a single magneton irradiated by two elliptically-polarized beams realizes a remarkable topological behavior, where it converts energy systematically (and with a universal rate) between one of the beams to the other, regardless of what their frequencies are. (see Fig. 2)

The intellectual merit of the work is evident in the need to develop new concepts that bring topological behavior to the field of photonics, as well as to disordered and interacting systems. We have developed a variety of new concepts that lead to the expansion of the realm of topological systems. The broader impacts of the work is evident in through the number of postdocs and students who continued to academic and industry positions. As importantly, our work was aimed at bringing topological quantum behavior closer to device applications in the realm of photonics. This continues to be the goal of our research.

fig 1: topolaritons sketch. By combining an optical cavity with a spin-orbit coupled semiconductor, and patterning a periodic structure on the semiconductor, an edge polariton could be stabilized, forming a topological polariton band, aka, a topolariton.

 

fig 2: topological frequency conversion. A spin-1/2 irradiated with two elliptically polarized beam could mimic a 2d topological phase, and become a photon amplifier. Energy is drawn from one beam and transfered to the other regardless of the frequency ratio.
